page.title: 11LANDSCAPE & BUILDINGS
page.content:
AKELEY WOOD is made up of a mixture of larch, crab, holly, conifers, rhododen- drons, oak, ash and sycamore. The cen- tral area is used for rearing young guinea fowl and game birds. A shooting syndicate of local people own the Wood. Land cover is mainly grazing with small areas of crops and rough pasture plus 10 active bee hives, producing some 200 lb of honey in a good year.
STOWE CASTLE was built in the early 18th century for Lord Cobham. It is a group of two-storied cottages with lean-to roofs against a curved, turret- ted stone wall with 5 square towers. See picture.
